sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: How full my heart is in my eyes appears,
What wants in words, I will supply in tears.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Come take your coach, your stuff, all must along,
Servants and all make ready, all be gone,
It was thy hand cut two hearts out of one.

div.stage: Enter sir Charles gentlemanlike, and his sister gentlewoman like.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.l: Brother, why have you tricked me like a bride?
Bought me this gay attire, these ornaments?
Forget you our estate, our poverty?

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.l: Call me not brother, but imagine me
Some barbarous outlaw, or uncivil kern,
For if thou shutst thy eye, and only hearst
The words that I shall utter, thou shalt judge me
Some staring ruffian, not thy brother Charles
O Susan.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.l: O brother, what doth this strange language mean?

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.l: Dost love me sister? Wouldst thou see me live
A bankrupt beggar in the world's disgrace,
And die indebted to my enemies?
Wouldst thou behold me stand like a huge beam
In the world's eye, a byword and a scorn?
It lies in thee of these to acquit me free,
And all my debt I may outstrip by thee.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.l: By me: why? I have nothing, nothing, left,
I owe even for the clothes upon my back,
I am not worth, etc.

sp.speaker: Charles
sp.l: O sister say not so,
It lies in you my downcast state to raise,
To make me stand on even points with the world:
Come sister, you are rich? Indeed you are:
And in your power you have, without delay,
Acton's five hundred pound back to repay.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.l: Till now I had thought you loud me, by mine honour
Which I had kept as spotless as the moon,
I ne'er was mistress of that single doit,
Which I reserved not to supply your wants:
And do you think that I would hoard from you.
Now by my hopes in heaven, knew I the means
To buy you from the slavery of your debts,
Especially from Acton whom I hate,
I would redeem it with my life or blood.

sp.speaker: Charles
sp.l: I challenge it, and kindred set apart
Thus russian like I lay siege to your ●art:
What do I owe to Acton?

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.l: Why some five hundred pounds, towards which I swear
In all the world I have not one dinar.

sp.speaker: Charles
sp.l: It will not prove so: sister, now resolve me,
What do you think, and speak your conscience?
Would Acton give might he enjoy your bed?

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.l: He would not shrink to spend a thousand pound,
To give the Mountford's name so deep a wound

sp.speaker: Charles
sp.l: A thousand pound, I but five hundred owe,
Grant him your bed, he'll paid with interest so.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.l: O brother:

sp.speaker: Charles
sp.l: O sister only this one way,
With that rich jewel you my debts may pay,
In speaking this my cold heart shakes with shame,
nor do I woo you in a brother's name,
But in a stranger's: shall I die in debt
To Acton my grand foe, and you still wear
The precious jewel that he holds so dear?

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.l: My honour I esteem as dear and precious,
As my redemption.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.l: I esteem you sister.
As dear, for so dear prizing it.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.l: Will Charles
Have me cut of my hands, and send them Acton:
Rip up my breast, and with my bleeding heart,
Present him as a token.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.l: Neither Jane:
But hear me in my strange assertion,
Thy honour and my soul are equal in my regard,
Nor will thy brother Charles survive thy shame,
His kindness like a burden hath surcharged me,
And under his good deeds I stooping go,
Not with an upright soul: had I remained
In prison still, there doubtless I had died:
Then unto him that freed me from that prison,
Still do I owe that life: what moved my foe
To enfranchise me? 'twas sister for your love?
With full five hundred pounds he bought your love,
And shall he not enjoy it? Shall the weight
Of all this heavy burden lean on me,
And will not you bear part? you did partake
The joy of my release, will you not stand
In joint bond bound to satisfy the debt,
Shall I be only charged?

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.l: But that I know
These arguments come from an honoured mind,
As in your most extremity of need,
Scorning to stand in debt to one you hate,
Nay rather would engage your unstained honour,
Than to be held ingrate, I should condemn you,
I see your resolution, and assent,
So Charles will have me, and I am content.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.l: For this I tricked you up.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.l: But here's a knife,
To save mine honour, shall slice out my life.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.l: I know thou pleasest me a thousand times
More in that resolution than thy grant:
Observe her love to soothe them in my suit,
Her honour she will hazard though not loose,
To bring me out of debt, her rigorous hand
Will pierce her heart: o wonder, that will choose
Rather than stain her blood, her life to lose.
Come, you sad sister to a woeful brother,
This is the gate: I'll bear him such a present,
Such an acquittance for the knight to seal
As will amaze his senses, and surprise
With admiration all his fantasies.

div.stage: Enter Acton and Malbie.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.l: Before his unchaste thoughts shall seize on me,
'Tis here shall my imprisoned soul set free.

sp.speaker: Acton.
sp.l: How: Mountford with his sister hand in hand,
What miracles a foot?

sp.speaker: Malby.
sp.l: It is a sight
Begets in me much admiration.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.l: Stand not amazed to see me thus attended,
Acton I owe thee money, and being unable
To bring thee the full sum ●o ready coin,
Lo for thy more assurance here's a pawn.
My sister, my dear sister, whose chaste honor
I prize above a million: here, nay take her,
She's worth your money man, do not foretake her.

sp.speaker: Francis.
sp.l: I would he were in earnest.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.l: Impute it not to my immodesty,
My brother being rich in nothing else
But in his interest that he hath in me,
According to his poverty hath brought you
Me, all her store, whom howsoe'er you prize
As forfeit to your hand, he values 〈…〉,
And would not sell, but to acquit your 〈◊〉
For any emperor's ransom.

sp.speaker: Francis.
sp.l: Stern heart, relent
thy former cruelty, at length repent;
Was ever known in any former age,
Such honourable wrested courtesy,
Lands, honours, lines, and all the world forgotten
Rather than stand engaged to such a foe.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.l: Acton she is too poor to be thy bride,
And I to much opposed to be thy brother,
There take her to thee, if thou hast the heart
To seize her as a rape or lustful prey,
To blur our house that never yet was stained,
To murder her that never meant thee harm,
To kill me now whom once thou savedst from death,
Do them at once on her, all these reli●
And perish with her spotted chastity.

sp.speaker: Francis
sp.l: You overcome me in your love sir Charles,
I cannot be so cruel to a lady
I love so dearely, since you have not spared
To engage your reputation to the world,
Your sister honour which you prize so dear,
Nay, all the comforts which you hold on earth
To grow out of my debt being your foe,
Your honoured thoughts, do thus I recompense
Your metamorphisd foe, receives your gift
In satisfaction of all former wrongs▪
This jewel I will wear, here in my heart,
And where before I thought her for her wants
Too base to be my bride, to end all strife,
I seal you my dear brother, her my wife.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.l: You still exceed us, I will yield to fate,
And learn to love, where I till now did hate.

sp.speaker: Charles
sp.l: With that enchantment you have charmed my soul,
And made me rich even in those very words,
I pay no debt but am indebted more
Rich in your love I never can be poor

sp.speaker: Francis.
sp.l: Alas mine is yours, we are alike in state,
Let's knit in love what was proposed in hate;
Come, for our nuptials we will straight provide,
Blessed only in our brother and fair bride. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Cranwell, Frankeford, and Nick.

sp.speaker: Cran.
sp.l: Why do you search each room about your house.
Now that you have dispatched your wife away?

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.l: O sir to see that nothing may be left
That ever was my wives, I loved her dear,
And when I do but think of her unkindness,
My thoughts are all in hell, to avoid which torment
I would not have a bodkin or a cuff,
A bracelet, necklace, or rebato wire,
Nor any thing that ever was hers,
Left me, by which I might remember her,
Seek round about?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.l: 'Sblood master, here's her lute stonge in a cornet,

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Her lute, o God upon this instrument,
Her fingers have run quick division,
Sweeter than that which now divides our hearts.
These frets have made me pleasant, that have now,
Frets of my heartstrings made, o master Cranwell,
Oft hath she made this melancholy wood,
Now mute and dumb for her disastrous chance,
Speak sweedy many a note, sound many a strain,
To her own ravishing voice which being well strung,
What pleasant strange airs have they jointly sung.
Post with it after her, now nothings left,
Of her, and hers, I am at once bereft.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.l: I'll ride and overtake her, do my message,
And come back again.

sp.speaker: Cran.
sp.l: Mean time sir, if you please,
I'll to sir Francis Acton, and inform him
Of what hath passed betwixt you and his sister.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Do as you please how ill am I bestead
To be a widower ere my wife be dead.

div.stage: Enter mistress Frankeford, with jenkin, her maid sislee, her coachman, and three carters.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: Bid my coach stay, why should I ride in state?
Being hurled so low down by the hand of fate.
A seat like to my fortunes let me have,
earth for my chair, and for my bed a grave.

sp.speaker: Jenkin.
sp.l: Comfort good mistress, you have watered your coach with tears already, you have but two mile now to go to your manor, a man cannot say by my old master Frankford as he may say by me, that he wants manners, for he hath three or four, of which this is one, that we are going to.

sp.speaker: Sisly.
sp.l: Good mistress be of good cheer, sorrow you see hurts you, but helps you not, we all mourn to see you so sad.

sp.speaker: Carter.
sp.l: Mistress I spy one of my landlord's men
Come riding post, 'tis like he brings some news.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: Comes he from master Frankford, he is welcome,
So are his news, because they come from him.

div.stage: Enter Nick.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.l: There.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: I know the lute, oft have I sung to thee,
We both are out of tune, both out of time.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.l: Would that had been the worst instrument that ere you played on: my master commends him to ye, theirs all he can find that was ever yours, he hath nothing left that ever you could claim to lay, but 〈◊〉 heart, and he could afford you that: all that I have to deliver you is this, he prays you to forget him, and so he bids your farewell.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: I thank him, he is kind and ever was,
All you that have true feeling of my grief,
That know my loss, and have relenting hearts,
Gird me about, and help me with your tears,
To wash my spotted sins, my lute shall grove
It cannot weep, but shall lament my moan.

div.stage: Enter Wendoll.

sp.speaker: Wendoll.
sp.l: Pursued with horror of a guilty soul,
And with the sharp scourge of repentance lashed,
I fly from my own shadow: o my stars
What have my parents in their lives deserved,
That you should lay this penance on their son?
When I but think of master Frankford's love,
And lay it to my treason, or compare
My murdering him for his relieving me,
It strikes a terror like a lightning's flash,
To search my blood up: thus I like the owl
ashamed of day, live in these shadowy woods
Afraid of every leaf or murmuring blast,
Yet longing to receive some perfect knowledge
How he hath dealt with her: o my sad fate,
Here, and so far from home, and thus attended:
O God, I have divorced the truest turtles
That ever lived together, and being divided
In several places, make their several moan;
She in the fields laments, and he at home.
So poets write that Orpheus made the trees,
And stones to dance, to his melodious harp,
Meaning the rustic and the barbarous hinds,
That had no understanding part in them,
So she from these rude carters tears extracts,
Making their flinty hearts with grief to rise,
And draw rivers from their rocky eyes.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: If you return unto your master say:
Though not from me, for I am all unworthy
To blast his name with a strumpet's tongue,
That you have seen me weep, wish myself dead:
Nay, you may say to, for my vow is past,
Last night you saw me eat and drink my last.
This to you master you may say and swear,
For it is writ in heaven and decreed here.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.l: I'll say you wept, I'll swear you made me sad,
Why how now eyes; what now, what's here to do?
I am gone, or I shall straight turn baby to.

sp.speaker: Wench
sp.l: I cannot weep, my heart is all on fire,
Cursed be the fruits of my unchaste desire.

sp.speaker: Anne
sp.l: Go break this lute my coaches wheel,
As the last music that I ere shall make,
Not as my husband's gift, but my farewell,
To all earth's joy, and so your master tell.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.l: If I can for crying.

sp.speaker: Wench
sp.l: Grief have done,
Or like a madman I shall frantic run.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: You have beheld the woefullest wretch on earth,
A woman made of tears, would you had words
to express but what you see: my inward grief
No tongue can utter, yet unto your power
You may describe my sorrow, and disclose
To thy sad master my abundant woes.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.l: I'll do your commendations.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: O no:
I dare not so presume, nor to my children,
I am disclaimed in both; alas I am,
O never teach them when they come to speak,
To name the name of mother: chide their tongue
If they by chance light on that hated word:
Tell them 'tis naught: for when that word they name,
Poor pretty souls they harp on their own shame.

sp.speaker: Wench
sp.l: To recompense her wrongs, what canst thou do?
Thou hast made her husbandless, and childless to.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: I have no more to say: speak not for me
Yet you may tell your master what you see?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.l: I'll doo●.Exit

sp.speaker: Wench
sp.l: I'll speak to her, and comfort her in grief,
O but her wound cannot be cured with words:
No matter though, I'll do my best good will,
To work a cure on her whom I did kill.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: So, now unto my coach, then to my home,
So to my deathbed, for from this sad hour,
I never will, nor eat, nor drink, nor taste
Of any cates that may preserve my life:
I never will nor smile, nor sleep, nor rest,
But when my tears have washed my black soul white,
Sweet saviour to thy hands I yield my sprite.

sp.speaker: Wench
sp.l: O mistress Frankford?

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: O for god's sake fly,
The devil doth come to tempt me ere I die:
My coach: this sin that with an angel's face,
Courted mine honour till he sought my wrack,
In my repentant eyes seems ugly black.

div.stage: Exeunt all: the carters whistling.

sp.speaker: Ienk.
sp.l:
What my young master that fled in his shirt, how come you by your clothes again? you have made our house in a sweet
pickle, have you not think you? What shall I serve you still, or cleave to the old house?

sp.speaker: Wench
sp.l: Hence slave, away with thy unseasoned mirth,
Unless thou canst shed tears, and sigh, and howl,
Curse thy sad fortunes, and exclaim on fate,
Thou art not for my turn.

sp.speaker: Ienk.
sp.l: Marry and you will not another will: farewell and be hanged, would you had never come to have kept this quoil within our doors, we shall ha' you run away like a sprite again.

sp.speaker: Wench
sp.l: Shees gone to death, I live to want and woe,
Her life, her sins, and all upon my head,
And I must now go wander like a Cain
In foreign countries, and remoted climes,
Where the report of my ingratitude
Cannot be heard, I'll over, first to France,
And so to Germany, and Italy,
Where when I have recovered, and by travel.
Got those perfect tongues, and that these rumours
May in their height abate, I will return,
And I divine, however now dejected
My worth and parts being by some great man praised,
At my return I may in court be raised. Exit.

div.stage: Enter sir Francis, sir Charles, Cranwell, and Susan.

sp.speaker: Francis.
sp.l: Brother, and now my wife, I think these troubles
Fall on my head, by justice of the heavens,
For being so strict to you in your extremities,
But we are now atoned, I would my sister
Could with like happiness, o'ercome her griefs,
As we have ours.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.l: You tell us master Cranwell wondrous things,
Touching the patience of that gentleman,
With what strange virtue he demeanes his grief.

sp.speaker: Cran.
sp.l: I told you what I was witness of▪
It was my fortune to lodge there that night.

sp.speaker: Francis.
sp.l: O that same villain Wendoll, was his tongue
That did corrupt her, she was of herself.
Chaste and devoted well. Is this the house?

sp.speaker: Cran.
sp.l: Yes sir, I take it here your sister lies.

sp.speaker: Francis.
sp.l: My brother Frankford showed too mild a spirit
In the revenge of such a loathed crime;
Less than he did, no man of spirit could do,
I am so far from blaming his revenge
That I commend it: had it been my case
Their souls at once had from their breasts been freed,
Death to such deeds of shame is the due meed.

div.stage: Enter Jenkin and Sislie.

sp.speaker: Ienk.
sp.l: O my mistress, my mistress, my poor mistress.

sp.speaker: Sislie.
sp.l: Alas that ever I was born, what shall I do, for my poor mistress.

sp.speaker: Charles,
sp.l: Why, what of her?

sp.speaker: Ienk.
sp.l: O lord sir, she no sooner heard that her brother
And his friends were come to see how she did,
But she for very shame of her guilty conscience, fell
Into a swoon, and we had much ado to
Get life into her.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.l: Alas that she should bear so hard a fate,
Pity it is, repentance comes too late.

sp.speaker: Acton.
sp.l: Is she so weak in body?

sp.speaker: Ienk.
sp.l: O sir I can assure you there's no help of life
In her, for she will take no sustenance, she hath plainly
Starved herself, that now she is as lean
As a lath, she ever
Looks for the good hour: many
Gentlemen and gentlewomen of the country are come to,
Comfort her.

div.stage: Enters mistress Frankeford in her bed.

sp.speaker: Malby.
sp.l: How fare you mistress Frankford?

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: Sick, sick, o sick, give me some air I pray you.
Tell me, o tell me, where's master Frankford?
Will not he deign to see me ere I die?

sp.speaker: Malby.
sp.l: Yes mistress Frankford, divers gentlemen,
Your loving neighbours with that just request,
Have moved and told him of your weak estate,
Who though with much ado to get belief.
Examining of the general circumstance,
Seeing your sorrow and your penitence
And hearing there withal the great desire
You have to see him ere you left the world,
He gave to us his faith to follow us,
And sure he will be here immediately.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: You half revived me with those pleasing news,
Raise me a little higher in my bed.
Blush I not master Frankford? blush I not sir Charles?
Can you not read my fault writ in my cheek?
Is not my crime there? tell me gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.l: Alas good mistress, sickness hath not left you
Blood in your face enough to make you blush:
Then sickness like a friend my fault would hide,

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: Is my husband come? My soul but tarries
His arrive and I am fit for heaven.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.l: I came to chide you, but my words of hate,
Are turned to pity and compassionate grief:
I came to rate you, but my bralles you see,
Melt into tears, and I must weep by thee.
Here's master Frankford now.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Good morrow brother, good morrow gentlemen,
God that hath laid this cross upon our heads,
Might had he pleased have made our cause of meeting
On a more fair and a more contented ground,
But he that made us, made us to this woe.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: And is he come, methinks that voice I know

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: How do you woman?

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: Well, master Frankford, well: but shall be better
I hope within this hour? will you vouchsafe
Out of your grace and your humanity,
To take a spotted strumpet by the hand?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: That hand once held my heart in faster bonds
Than now 'tis gripped by me: God pardon them
That made us first break hold.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: Amen, amen,
Out of my zeal to heaven whither I am now bound,
I was so impudent to wish you here,
And once more beg your pardon o good man.
And father to my children pardon me.
Pardon, o pardon me, my fault so heinous is,
That if you in this world forgive it not,
Heaven will not clear it in the world to come.
Faintness hath so usurped upon my knees,
That kneel I cannot ● but on my heart's knees,
My prostrate soul lies thrown down at your feet,
To beg your gracious pardon: pardon, oh pardon me.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: As freely from the low depth of my soul,
As my redeemer hath forgiven his death,
I pardon thee, I will shed tears for thee,
Pray with thee, and in mere pity
Of thy weak state, I'll wish to die with thee.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: So do we all▪

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.l: So will not I,
I'll sigh and sob, but by my faith not die.

sp.speaker: Acton
sp.l: O master Frankford all the near alliance,
I lose by her, shall be supplied in thee,
You are my brother by the nearest way,
Her kindred hath fallen off, but yours doth stay.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Even as I hope for pardon at that day,
When the great judge of heaven in scarlet sits,
So be thou pardoned, though thy rash offence,
Divorced our bodies, thy repentant tears
Unite our souls.

sp.speaker: Charles
sp.l: Then comfort mistress Frankford,
You see your husband hath forgiven your fall,
Then rouse your spirits, and cheere your fainting soul.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.l: How is it with you?

sp.speaker: Acton.
sp.l: How do you feel yourself?

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: Not of this world.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: I see you are not, and I weep to see it,
My wife the mother to my pretty babes,
Both those lost names I do restore thee back.
And with this kiss I wed thee once again,
Though thou art wounded in thy honoured name,
And with that grief upon thy deathbed liest,
Honest in heart, upon my soul thou diest.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: Pardoned on earth, soul, thou in heaven art free,
Once more thy wife, dies thus embracing thee.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: New married, and new widowed, o she's dead,
And a cold grave must be our nuptial bed.

sp.speaker: Charles
sp.l: Sir be of good comfort, and your heavy sorrow,
Part equally amongst us, storms divided
Abate their force, and with less rage are guided.

sp.speaker: Cran.
sp.l: Do master Frankford, he that hath least part,
Will find enough to drown one troubled heart.

sp.speaker: Acton.
sp.l: Peace with thee Nan: brothers and gentlemen,
All we that can plead interest in her grief
Bestow upon her body funeral tears;
Brother, had you with threats and usage bad,
Punished her sin, the grief of her offence
Had not with such true sorrow touched her heart.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: I see it had not, therefore on her grave,
I will bestow this funeral epitaph,
Which on her marble tomb shall be engraved,
In golden letters shall these words be filled,
Here lies she, whom her husband's kindness killed.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
